Gold rose to its highest level in almost two months, while the Swiss franc increased by more than 1% against the US dollar and saw its biggest one-day gain against the euro in more than two and a half years. South Koreaâ€™s won currency dropped 0.9% against the dollar.

Kathleen Brooks, research director at City Index Direct, said: â€œThe Swiss franc is the safe haven of choice today as risk sentiment gets hit from escalating nuclear fears between the US and North Korea. Unsurprisingly, the yen, which is still the second best performer in the G10 foreign exchange space, is playing second fiddle to the Swiss franc due to Japanâ€™s proximity to the epicentre in Pyongyang.â€�

Shares fell in Asian and European trading after Pyongyang responded to the US presidentâ€™s tough language with a threat to launch a nuclear strike on the US Pacific territory of Guam.

Tokyoâ€™s Nikkei index had dropped 1.3% by the time European stock markets opened on Wednesday morning, with similar falls on the German and French bourses. The FTSE 100 ended 44.67 points lower at 7498.06.

But the prospect of hefty losses on Wall Street stocks was averted when US secretary of state Rex Tillerson said there was â€œno imminent threat of warâ€� and that Americans could â€œsleep well at nightâ€�....

More here:

Related: Investors move to safe havens as US and North Korea trade threats

5.04pm BST

European markets close in the red

After a tense, and sometimes sodden day, Londonâ€™s stock market has closed for the day.

Fears over North Korea wiped 0.6% off the blue-chip FTSE 100, with banks and mining companies among the fallers.

There were steeper losses in Europe, though, with the French CAC losing 1.3% and Germanyâ€™ DAX down 1.1%

Markets did recover from their lowest points, after US secretary of state Rex Tillerson told Americans they could sleep safely.

But investors are still nervous, as Joshua Mahony of IG says:

European stocks have stabilised after this morningâ€™s fear-fuelled deterioration in response to heightened fears of a US-North Korea conflict. Although the stock markets have regained some ground, concerns clearly remain over the potential of conflict, with US yields hitting a six-week low and gold and JPYUSD hitting near two-month highs.

David Madden of CMC Markets reckons markets could remain edgy until the crisis is resolved.

European stocks have suffered greatly today as traders were prompted to cut-and-run due to the escalating tensions between the US and North Korea. The stand-off between the two countries has encouraged dealers to dump stocks and seek safe haven investments like gold. While the two nations are at loggerheads, it is going to be difficult to imagine money flowing into stocks.

Over in America, Wall Street is still in the red, with safe-haven stocks in demand. The Dow Jones industrial average is currently down 50 points, or 0.2%, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq index has lost 0.5%.

On that note, itâ€™s time for a break - but Iâ€™ll be back if anything dramatic happens... GW

4.21pm BST

There arenâ€™t many precedents, fortunately, for how the financial world reacts to the threat of nuclear destruction.

The best example is 1962, and the Cuban missile crisis.

Capital Economics have dug into the data, and report that the early selloff didnâ€™t last long:

Although the S&P 500 fell after US President Kennedy announced the discovery of missiles on Cuba, it had more or less recovered its losses before Soviet General Secretary Khrushchev announced six days later that the missiles would be removed from the island.

And even the initial fall was very small compared to the declines in US equities earlier that year, which were not connected to the crisis

3.38pm BST

Thereâ€™s relief in the City that Wall Street hasnâ€™t suffered chunkier losses so far today.

European markets are recovering some of their earlier losses, on hopes that the North Korea - US standoff wonâ€™t lead to real disaster.

Connor Campbell of SpreadEx says:

While the markets pulled back from their lunchtime losses, the US open couldnâ€™t convince investors to put their Trump/North Korea fears to one side.

Though the Dow Jones largely managed to avoid the kind of drastic downturn seen by its European counterparts, it still fell 60 odd points after the bell, leaving the index just above the 22000 mark. For most of Trumpâ€™s tenure the Dow has left the dollar to deal with the Presidentâ€™s constant policy disappointments, so it will be interesting to see whether todayâ€™s drop marks a change in direction for the record-breaking index, or if it is merely a knee-jerk blip exacerbated by an empty economic calendar.

2.40pm BST

Wall Street joins the selloff

DING DING! The New York stock market has opened for the day with some losses, as investors follow Europe and Asiaâ€™s lead.

The Dow Jones industrial average has dropped by 62 points, as the escalating tensions between America and North Korea loom over the trading floors.

Thatâ€™s a drop of 0.3%, adding to yesterdayâ€™s losses after Donald Trump warned North Korea to expect â€˜fire and furyâ€™ if it made any moves against the US.

Goldman Sachs have suggested that investors are actually more worried than theyâ€™re letting on.....

2.29pm BST

How Korean Conflict would hurt global economy

Capital Economics have calculated that the global economy would take a significant hit if armed conflict broke out between the US and North Korea.

In a research note published today, they say:

The most important impact of a full-scale conflict on the Korean peninsula would be a massive loss of life. But there would also be significant economic consequences.

Those consequences include major damage to South Koreaâ€™s economy, and a knock-on impact to supply chains around the globe. The technology industry would be particularly hurt, they warn.

The war in Syria has led to a 60% fall in the countryâ€™s GDP. The most devastating military conflict since World War Two, however, has been the Korean War (1950-53), which led to 1.2m South Korean deaths, and saw the value of its GDP fall by over 80%. ï‚· South Korea accounts for around 2% of global economic output. A 50% fall in South Korean GDP would directly knock 1% off global GDP. But there would also be indirect effects to consider. The main one is the disruption it would cause to global supply chains, which have been made more vulnerable by the introduction of just-in-time delivery systems. Months after the Thai floods had receded in 2011 electronics and automotive factories across the world were still reporting shortages.

The impact of a war in Korea would be much bigger. South Korea exports three times as many intermediate products as Thailand. In particular, South Korea is the biggest producer of liquid crystal displays in the world (40% of the global total) and the second biggest of semiconductors (17% market share). It is also a key automotive manufacturer and home to the worldâ€™s three biggest shipbuilders. If South Korean production was badly damaged by a war there would be shortages across the world. The disruption would last for some time â€“ it takes around two years to build a semi-conductor factory from scratch.

The impact of the war on the US economy would likely be significant, Capital Economics adds:

At its peak in 1952, the US government was spending the equivalent of 4.2% of its GDP fighting the Korean War. The total cost of the second Gulf War (2003) and its aftermath has been estimated at US$1trn (5% of one yearâ€™s US GDP). A prolonged war in Korea would significantly push up US federal debt, which at 75% of GDP is already uncomfortably high.

1.48pm BST

Selloff deepens in Europe

The losses in the European stock markets are intensifying, as traders brace for further developments.

Hereâ€™s the latest.

  • Britain FTSE 100: down 62 points, or 0.8%, at 7480 points
  • German DAX: down 182 points, or 1.5%, at 12,109 points
  • French CAC: down 68 points, or 1.7%, at 4029 points

Investors arenâ€™t sure if this is a knee-jerk reaction to last nightâ€™s war of words between the US and North Korea, or the start of a serious selloff after a string of record highs.

Fawad Razaqzada of Forex.com says the next few hours could be critical.

By the close of the bell tonight we should have a good feel for sentiment one way or another. But as things stand, risk is definitely off the menu and if you-know-what hits the fan then things could turn ugly really quick.

This is especially the case given the extent of the recent rally, which means there will be lots of stops resting below market. So, the downward move could gather pace due to technical selling.

1.38pm BST

Money is pouring into US government bonds as New York traders reach their desks and pile into safe-haven assets.

This has driven the price of these Treasury bills up, sending the interest rate (or yield) on the bonds down to their lowest levels in six weeks.

1.29pm BST

The US president has weighed in again....

1.06pm BST

A quick look at the best-performing shares in London shows that investors are preparing for a potential conflict in Korea.

Gold producer Randgold and silver producer Fresnillo have both jumped by 3%, following the surge in precious metal prices today.

Weapons producer BAE Systems has also rallied, on the prospect of increased military spending on munitions, armoured vehicles and the like.

Kathleen Brooks of City Index explains:

BAE Systems, the weapons and defence company, has managed to pick up off recent lows, and is 1.5% higher so far on Wednesday.

We would expect US defence companies to also fair well on Wednesday with Lockheed Martin, Boeing and Northrup Gruman potential gainers from the escalating geopolitical situation with North Korea.

12.59pm BST

Hereâ€™s our latest explainer:

Related: North Korea v the US: how likely is war?

12.52pm BST

European banks are bearing the brunt of todayâ€™s selloff.

The sector has fallen by 1.8% today, on track for its worst day in three months.

12.43pm BST

Hereâ€™s the answer to this morningâ€™s question about how Brexit is making it harder to regulate the City of London:

Updated at 12.58pm BST

12.31pm BST

The financial markets could suffer sharp losses if the US and North Korea donâ€™t calm the situation.

So says Stuart Culverhouse, global head of macro & fixed income research at investment bank Exotix Capital:

â€œThe North Korean threat has been present in one form or another for some time, and despite periods of nervousness, markets generally have not tended to focus on it too much.

â€œNow, with the tension between the US and DPRK reaching a level that appears somewhat unprecedented in the last decade, if not longer, the question is whether this time is different.

â€œTime will tell, but markets may look to safe haven assets if things escalate. The best hope is for all parties to return to the negotiating table.

12.30pm BST

12.28pm BST

More from Rex Tillerson, who is trying to give US citizens some early morning reassurance (itâ€™s almost 7.30am on the East coast):

12.21pm BST

Rex Tillerson: No imminent threat from North Korea

Breaking: Americaâ€™s secretary of state, Rex Tillerson, has told Americans not to panic about an imminent attack from North Korea.

Updated at 12.42pm BST

12.15pm BST

Although European and Asian stock markets have been hit by North Korean fears today, the US stock market is expected to open fairly calmly.

The futures market suggests the Dow will fall by 30 or 40 points, so only a small dip.

However the â€˜fearâ€™ index, the VIX, has jumped to its highest level in a month - showing that investors are anxious.

Updated at 3.00pm BST

11.22am BST

North Korea isnâ€™t the only thing worrying investors today

Investors are also spooked by reports that a car has ploughed into a group of French soldiers in Paris this morning.

Joshua Mahony of IG says geopolitical worries are driving the markets.

European markets are trading in the red this morning, as the risk aversion caused by further confrontation between the US and North Korean was exacerbated heightened by another attack taking place in Paris....

A week of low volatility has been hit with an unexpected rush to safe havens as the US-North Korean feud has ratcheted up once more overnight. No sooner had Trump warned of â€˜fire and furyâ€™ in the event of further threats from North Korea, than the breakaway nation responded with exactly just such a threat, announcing plans for a potential attack on the US airbase in Guam. The unpredictable nature of North Korea means it is hard to gauge exactly how likely an attack is, yet given the military power of both nations, there is no surprise we are seeing markets shift out of risk assets and into havens such as the yen and gold.

With the height of the 2007 crisis falling 10 years ago, the threat of a nuclear conflict represents the best chance we have of another market crash.

11.10am BST

Safe money havens such as the Swiss franc have received â€œa booster shotâ€� from the US-North Korea crisis, says Arnaud Masset of Swissquote Bank.

This chart shows how the â€˜Swissieâ€™ is the best-performing major currency against the US dollar today.

10.50am BST

The Bank of England has also announced it will appoint a â€˜conflicts of interestâ€™ officer.

It follows deputy governor Charlotte Hoggâ€™s shock resignation from the BoE this year, after she failed to report that her brother worked for Barclays bank.

10.24am BST

UK firms struggling to hire staff, says Bank of England

British companies are finding it harder to recruit staff, according to the latest report from the Bank of Englandâ€™s agents across the UK.

But despite being in shorter supply, workers arenâ€™t getting higher pay rises. Thatâ€™s disappointing, given the recent jump in inflation.

The latest Agentsâ€™ summary of business conditions, just released, says:

Recruitment difficulties had edged higher, and were gradually broadening across sectors and skill areas. Despite this, labour cost growth had been modest, with pay awards clustered around 2%â€“3%.

The BoEâ€™s agents also found that UK companies only have â€˜modestâ€™ hiring intentions right now. Manufacturers are more focused on improving productivity and automating tasks, rather than taking on more staff, they add.

10.16am BST

Just in: Greeceâ€™s inflation rate remained at 1% last month, as the country continues to claw its way out of deflation.

9.54am BST

European shares are still falling

The selloff is gathering pace, as worries over potential military conflict between the US and North Korea grips the markets.

Britainâ€™s FTS 100 is now down almost 60 points at 7481, a drop of 0.8%, extending its earlier losses.

There are losses in France and Germany too, as traders fret that Donald Trump may mishandle the North Korea crisis, with potentially devastating consequences.

Michael Hewson of CMC Markets explains why the City is worried by last nightâ€™s comments from Trump and the North Korean side.

Rising tensions on the Korean peninsula are nothing new, they have been a staple for investors for several years now, but this flare-up has the potential for a policy misstep, more so because of the inexperience of the person occupying the White House, and a tendency to conduct policy by way of tweet and press conference. This may explain why financial markets have adopted a safety first approach to events over the last twelve hours.

Last nightâ€™s comments from President Trump that North Korea would face â€œfire and fury like the world has never seenâ€�, if they continued to threaten the US along with their attempts to build a nuclear warhead, that could hit the western US, brought an entirely predictable counter response from Pyongyang.

The response that the North Korean nation was considering a missile strike on the US base in Guam was the equivalent of a two fingered response to the US President, and there is a danger that this war of words between two leaders with large egos could get out of control.

Updated at 10.01am BST

9.50am BST

Hindsightâ€™s a wonderful thing, so where should you have put your money 10 years ago as the financial sector began implode?

Deutsche Bank has the answers - the American stock market, and high-yielding US debt.

You should have kept well away from the Greek stock market, European banks, and oil.

Hope that helps...

9.42am BST

Former BoE deputy governor: 2008 won't happen again

We wonâ€™t see a rerun of the 2008 financial crisis according to Sir John Gieve, the Bank of Englandâ€™s deputy governor for financial stability between 2006 and 2009.

He told BBC Radio 4â€™s Today programme:

â€œI donâ€™t think weâ€™ll see a repeat of what happened 10 years ago because banks have far more capital, there are far more regulations on their liquidity and funding which was a big issue then, and of course they have spent the last 10 years dealing with the problems raised ... so there isnâ€™t the exuberance that we certainly saw then.â€�

Gieve said that debt levels in the UK were more manageable now, but flagged up concerns about the situation in China:

â€œIn the UK and most of the west the debt levels are more manageable now. Weâ€™ve yet to see how they will be affected by a return of positive interest rates, because weâ€™ve had 10 years of super expansionist monetary policy and weâ€™ve yet to see how we can get out of that.

â€œThe main debt which threatens a sudden break is probably in the far East and China which has been running a credit binge now for a decade and is showing signs of over extension.â€�

9.42am BST

Hereâ€™s a neat chart, showing how world stock markets have clawed back their financial crisis losses, but anyone holding bank shares is still nursing losses.

Some banks are *still* dealing with the consequences of the crisis. Royal Bank of Scotland, for example, remains under taxpayer control and continues to negotiate with the US department of justice over misconduct in the run-up to 2007.

9.24am BST

Politicians have failed to obey Churchillâ€™s advice to â€œNever let a good crisis go to wasteâ€�, says Torsten Bell of the Resolution Foundation.

Bell writes that there was a great opportunity to reform the economy in the 10 years since the credit crunch, but it has been missed.

After the second world war the Attlee government didnâ€™t simply try to undo the damage of the war. From the NHS to our national parks, it used the energy from that cataclysm to build a better Britain. Franklin D Rooseveltâ€™s New Deal wasnâ€™t simply a response to the Great Depression, but a set of interlocking reforms aiming to build a fairer country.

The financial crisis highlighted the big challenge of our time: to ensure the economy delivers for working people. Looking back over the last decade, itâ€™s clear we have far from delivered. With Brexit looming, a lotâ€™s changed in our politics.

But when it comes to our economy, things simply havenâ€™t changed anywhere near enough.

Related: We let the 2007 financial crisis go to waste | Torsten Bell

9.14am BST

Jack Lew: We must remember the lessons of the crisis

Jack Lew, former US Treasury Secretary, has been reminiscing about the financial crisis to mark the 10th anniversary of the credit crunch.

He told Radio 4â€™s Today Programme that in 2008 he was was â€œquietly advisingâ€� future president Barack Obama on how to address the economic and financial crisis.

â€œIâ€™d never seen a situation where every single day numbers were so much different and worse than the day before that you literally had to come back and keep revisiting how much fiscal stimulus would the economy need in order to stimulate a recovery.

Lew also warned that memories of the financial crisis may be starting to fade, and people may forget why some key reforms were pushed through.

â€œWe all know that crises will come in the future, what we donâ€™t know is when and how. What Wall Street reform did was for the first time since the Great Depression gave us the ability to have tools where we could deal with an evolving financial system to have the safeguards that we need. Even before this election you saw a great pushback amongst many, saying this has gone too far.

I fear that as the memory of the Great Recession and the financial crisis start to dim, some of the simple nostrums about just clearing away regulation, start to take on salience as if the stakes were not so high in 2007/2008.

Updated at 9.19am BST

9.07am BST

Overnight, the Bank of England has warned that the task of regulating the City after Brexit will put a strain on its ability to police the financial sector.

Like to know more? Let us know what youâ€™d like answered and weâ€™ll do the rest....

8.55am BST

The rising US-North Korean nuclear tensions have dampened appetite for risky assets like equities and industrial commodities, says Mike van Dulken of Accendo Markets.

Instead, safe assets like gold, silver, bonds, the Japanese Yen and the Swiss Franc are in demand, he adds.

8.45am BST

One City worker reports that senior investors are taking steps to protect themselves from the risks of conflict between the US and North Korea

PMs are portfolio managers, or someone who manages other peopleâ€™s money

8.31am BST

Europe joins the selloff

European stock markets are a sea of red in early trading, with the main indices down around 0.5%.

Naeem Aslam of Think Markets explains:

The geopolitical tensions have prompted a risk off trade amid investors. President Trumpâ€™s comments about North Korea have created nervousness and the fear is if the president really means what he said â€œfire and furyâ€�.

Updated at 8.46am BST

8.23am BST

The Japanese yen has hit an eight-week high against the dollar, as geopolitical worries hit the Asian markets.

Thatâ€™s significant, as the yen is a classic safe-haven in turbulent times. Todayâ€™s moves drove it up to Â¥109.74, from Â¥110.37 on Tuesday.

Mitsuo Imaizumi, chief FX strategist at Daiwa Securities, says (via Reuters) that North Koreaâ€™s threat to attack the island of Guam has spooked traders.

â€œThe market had been complacent for a while regarding headlines from North Korea. So it reacted when the North threatened Guam,

â€œFew participants, however, think that North Korea would actually strike Guam at this juncture. So the impact is likely to fade eventually.â€�

8.15am BST

Trumpâ€™s warning to North Korea also sparked a late sell-off on Wall Street last night.

That meant the Dow Jones industrial average couldnâ€™t hit its 10th record high in a row.

8.01am BST

The agenda: Markets rattled by Trump and North Korea's threats

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and business.

Thereâ€™s an old saying in the markets that you should â€œbuy at the sound of cannonsâ€�.

Todayâ€™s mantra, though, is that you should sell when the president of the United States and leader of North Korea threaten each other with military conflict.

Asian shares have been rattled overnight by the news that Donald Trump had told journalists in New Jersey that:

â€œNorth Korea best not make any more threats to the United States. They will be met with fire and the fury like the world has never seen.â€�

Trump was responding to reports that North Korea had produced a miniaturised nuclear weapon that can be carried on its intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM). This move raises fears that Pyongyang could launch a pre-emptive attack on the US.

As we reported last night:

â€œI donâ€™t have the slightest doubt that the RVs on these missiles are working,â€� said Jeffrey Lewis, the director of the East Asia nonproliferation programme at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey.

â€œThatâ€™s done. Weâ€™re there. North Korea can put a nuclear weapon on New York City.â€�

Related: Donald Trump vows to answer North Korea nuclear threats with 'fire and fury'

North Korea swiftly responded to Trumpâ€™s comments, with reports that it was considering attacking the US Pacific territory of Guam, which is a significant US military base.

Related: Donald Trump vows to answer North Korea nuclear threats with 'fire and fury'

This has a predictably bad effect on the markets, driving money into safe-haven assets such as US government bonds, and out of shares.

Japanâ€™s Nikkei index tumbled by 1.5%, while South Koreaâ€™s Kospi 200 index lost 1.25% as traders in Seoul watched events nervously.

Itâ€™s not a full-blown crash, of course, but investors do seem to be concerned by the escalating tensions

â€œMarkets have a mostly consistent risk-off tone overnight,â€� says Adam Cole of RBC Capital Markets.

Weâ€™re also expecting losses in Europe today, with the FTSE 100 being called down 35 points.

Jasper Lawler of CMC Markets says:

North Korea has been a worry simmering in the background for a long time but with its more advanced weapons and Trump ready to act in the White House, it could bubble over anytime.

The threat from North Korea seems to have jolted investors out of their summer slumber.

This will also overshadow the 10th anniversary of the financial crisis, which is being marked today.

August 9th 2007 was the â€œday the world changedâ€� when central bankers began pumping money into the system, after French bank BNP Paribas barred investors from accessing money in funds exposed to subprime mortgages industry.

Related: Credit fears hit global markets

That was the formal start of the credit crunch, which let to market mayhem, bank collapses, a global recession and the eurozone debt crisis. Weâ€™ll be looking back at what weâ€™ve learned since.

The agenda:

  • 10am BST: Bank of England publishes report on how it handles conflicts of interest
  • 10am BST: Greek consumer price inflation figures

Updated at 8.16am BST

The disruption would last for some time â€“ it takes around two years to build a semi-conductor factory from scratch. The impact of the war on the US economy would likely be significant, Capital Economics adds: At its peak in 1952, the US government was spending the equivalent of 4.2% of its GDP fighting the Korean War. The total cost of the second Gulf War (2003) and its aftermath has been estimated at US$1trn (5% of one yearâ€™s US GDP). A prolonged war in Korea would significantly push up US federal debt, which at 75% of GDP is already uncomfortably high. The losses in the European stock markets are intensifying, as traders brace for further developments. Hereâ€™s the latest. Britain FTSE 100: down 62 points, or 0.8%, at 7480 points German DAX: down 182 points, or 1.5%, at 12,109 points French CAC: down 68 points, or 1.7%, at 4029 points Investors arenâ€™t sure if this is a knee-jerk reaction to last nightâ€™s war of words between the US and North Korea, or the start of a serious selloff after a string of record highs. Fawad Razaqzada of Forex.com says the next few hours could be critical. By the close of the bell tonight we should have a good feel for sentiment one way or another. But as things stand, risk is definitely off the menu and if you-know-what hits the fan then things could turn ugly really quick. This is especially the case given the extent of the recent rally, which means there will be lots of stops resting below market. So, the downward move could gather pace due to technical selling. Money is pouring into US government bonds as New York traders reach their desks and pile into safe-haven assets. This has driven the price of these Treasury bills up, sending the interest rate (or yield) on the bonds down to their lowest levels in six weeks. The US president has weighed in again.... A quick look at the best-performing shares in London shows that investors are preparing for a potential conflict in Korea. Gold producer Randgold and silver producer Fresnillo have both jumped by 3%, following the surge in precious metal prices today. Weapons producer BAE Systems has also rallied, on the prospect of increased military spending on munitions, armoured vehicles and the like. Kathleen Brooks of City Index explains: BAE Systems, the weapons and defence company, has managed to pick up off recent lows, and is 1.5% higher so far on Wednesday. We would expect US defence companies to also fair well on Wednesday with Lockheed Martin, Boeing and Northrup Gruman potential gainers from the escalating geopolitical situation with North Korea. Hereâ€™s our latest explainer: European banks are bearing the brunt of todayâ€™s selloff. The sector has fallen by 1.8% today, on track for its worst day in three months. Hereâ€™s the answer to this morningâ€™s question about how Brexit is making it harder to regulate the City of London: The financial markets could suffer sharp losses if the US and North Korea donâ€™t calm the situation. So says Stuart Culverhouse, global head of macro & fixed income research at investment bank Exotix Capital: â€œThe North Korean threat has been present in one form or another for some time, and despite periods of nervousness, markets generally have not tended to focus on it too much. â€œNow, with the tension between the US and DPRK reaching a level that appears somewhat unprecedented in the last decade, if not longer, the question is whether this time is different. â€œTime will tell, but markets may look to safe haven assets if things escalate. The best hope is for all parties to return to the negotiating table. More from Rex Tillerson, who is trying to give US citizens some early morning reassurance (itâ€™s almost 7.30am on the East coast): Breaking: Americaâ€™s secretary of state, Rex Tillerson, has told Americans not to panic about an imminent attack from North Korea. Although European and Asian stock markets have been hit by North Korean fears today, the US stock market is expected to open fairly calmly. The futures market suggests the Dow will fall by 30 or 40 points, so only a small dip. However the â€˜fearâ€™ index, the VIX, has jumped to its highest level in a month - showing that investors are anxious. North Korea isnâ€™t the only thing worrying investors today Investors are also spooked by reports that a car has ploughed into a group of French soldiers in Paris this morning. Joshua Mahony of IG says geopolitical worries are driving the markets. European markets are trading in the red this morning, as the risk aversion caused by further confrontation between the US and North Korean was exacerbated heightened by another attack taking place in Paris.... A week of low volatility has been hit with an unexpected rush to safe havens as the US-North Korean feud has ratcheted up once more overnight. No sooner had Trump warned of â€˜fire and furyâ€™ in the event of further threats from North Korea, than the breakaway nation responded with exactly just such a threat, announcing plans for a potential attack on the US airbase in Guam. The unpredictable nature of North Korea means it is hard to gauge exactly how likely an attack is, yet given the military power of both nations, there is no surprise we are seeing markets shift out of risk assets and into havens such as the yen and gold. With the height of the 2007 crisis falling 10 years ago, the threat of a nuclear conflict represents the best chance we have of another market crash. Safe money havens such as the Swiss franc have received â€œa booster shotâ€� from the US-North Korea crisis, says Arnaud Masset of Swissquote Bank. This chart shows how the â€˜Swissieâ€™ is the best-performing major currency against the US dollar today. The Bank of England has also announced it will appoint a â€˜conflicts of interestâ€™ officer. It follows deputy governor Charlotte Hoggâ€™s shock resignation from the BoE this year, after she failed to report that her brother worked for Barclays bank. British companies are finding it harder to recruit staff, according to the latest report from the Bank of Englandâ€™s agents across the UK. But despite being in shorter supply, workers arenâ€™t getting higher pay rises. Thatâ€™s disappointing, given the recent jump in inflation. The latest Agentsâ€™ summary of business conditions, just released, says: Recruitment difficulties had edged higher, and were gradually broadening across sectors and skill areas. Despite this, labour cost growth had been modest, with pay awards clustered around 2%â€“3%. The BoEâ€™s agents also found that UK companies only have â€˜modestâ€™ hiring intentions right now. Manufacturers are more focused on improving productivity and automating tasks, rather than taking on more staff, they add. Just in: Greeceâ€™s inflation rate remained at 1% last month, as the country continues to claw its way out of deflation. The selloff is gathering pace, as worries over potential military conflict between the US and North Korea grips the markets. Britainâ€™s FTS 100 is now down almost 60 points at 7481, a drop of 0.8%, extending its earlier losses. There are losses in France and Germany too, as traders fret that Donald Trump may mishandle the North Korea crisis, with potentially devastating consequences. Michael Hewson of CMC Markets explains why the City is worried by last nightâ€™s comments from Trump and the North Korean side. Rising tensions on the Korean peninsula are nothing new, they have been a staple for investors for several years now, but this flare-up has the potential for a policy misstep, more so because of the inexperience of the person occupying the White House, and a tendency to conduct policy by way of tweet and press conference. This may explain why financial markets have adopted a safety first approach to events over the last twelve hours. Last nightâ€™s comments from President Trump that North Korea would face â€œfire and fury like the world has never seenâ€�, if they continued to threaten the US along with their attempts to build a nuclear warhead, that could hit the western US, brought an entirely predictable counter response from Pyongyang. The response that the North Korean nation was considering a missile strike on the US base in Guam was the equivalent of a two fingered response to the US President, and there is a danger that this war of words between two leaders with large egos could get out of control. Hindsightâ€™s a wonderful thing, so where should you have put your money 10 years ago as the financial sector began implode? Deutsche Bank has the answers - the American stock market, and high-yielding US debt. You should have kept well away from the Greek stock market, European banks, and oil. Hope that helps... We wonâ€™t see a rerun of the 2008 financial crisis according to Sir John Gieve, the Bank of Englandâ€™s deputy governor for financial stability between 2006 and 2009. He told BBC Radio 4â€™s Today programme: â€œI donâ€™t think weâ€™ll see a repeat of what happened 10 years ago because banks have far more capital, there are far more regulations on their liquidity and funding which was a big issue then, and of course they have spent the last 10 years dealing with the problems raised ... so there isnâ€™t the exuberance that we certainly saw then.â€� Gieve said that debt levels in the UK were more manageable now, but flagged up concerns about the situation in China: â€œIn the UK and most of the west the debt levels are more manageable now. Weâ€™ve yet to see how they will be affected by a return of positive interest rates, because weâ€™ve had 10 years of super expansionist monetary policy and weâ€™ve yet to see how we can get out of that. â€œThe main debt which threatens a sudden break is probably in the far East and China which has been running a credit binge now for a decade and is showing signs of over extension.â€� Hereâ€™s a neat chart, showing how world stock markets have clawed back their financial crisis losses, but anyone holding bank shares is still nursing losses. Some banks are *still* dealing with the consequences of the crisis. Royal Bank of Scotland, for example, remains under taxpayer control and continues to negotiate with the US department of justice over misconduct in the run-up to 2007. Politicians have failed to obey Churchillâ€™s advice to â€œNever let a good crisis go to wasteâ€�, says Torsten Bell of the Resolution Foundation. Bell writes that there was a great opportunity to reform the economy in the 10 years since the credit crunch, but it has been missed. After the second world war the Attlee government didnâ€™t simply try to undo the damage of the war. From the NHS to our national parks, it used the energy from that cataclysm to build a better Britain. Franklin D Rooseveltâ€™s New Deal wasnâ€™t simply a response to the Great Depression, but a set of interlocking reforms aiming to build a fairer country. The financial crisis highlighted the big challenge of our time: to ensure the economy delivers for working people. Looking back over the last decade, itâ€™s clear we have far from delivered. With Brexit looming, a lotâ€™s changed in our politics. But when it comes to our economy, things simply havenâ€™t changed anywhere near enough. Jack Lew, former US Treasury Secretary, has been reminiscing about the financial crisis to mark the 10th anniversary of the credit crunch. He told Radio 4â€™s Today Programme that in 2008 he was was â€œquietly advisingâ€� future president Barack Obama on how to address the economic and financial crisis. â€œIâ€™d never seen a situation where every single day numbers were so much different and worse than the day before that you literally had to come back and keep revisiting how much fiscal stimulus would the economy need in order to stimulate a recovery. Lew also warned that memories of the financial crisis may be starting to fade, and people may forget why some key reforms were pushed through. â€œWe all know that crises will come in the future, what we donâ€™t know is when and how. What Wall Street reform did was for the first time since the Great Depression gave us the ability to have tools where we could deal with an evolving financial system to have the safeguards that we need. Even before this election you saw a great pushback amongst many, saying this has gone too far. I fear that as the memory of the Great Recession and the financial crisis start to dim, some of the simple nostrums about just clearing away regulation, start to take on salience as if the stakes were not so high in 2007/2008. Overnight, the Bank of England has warned that the task of regulating the City after Brexit will put a strain on its ability to police the financial sector. Like to know more? Let us know what youâ€™d like answered and weâ€™ll do the rest.... The rising US-North Korean nuclear tensions have dampened appetite for risky assets like equities and industrial commodities, says Mike van Dulken of Accendo Markets. Instead, safe assets like gold, silver, bonds, the Japanese Yen and the Swiss Franc are in demand, he adds. One City worker reports that senior investors are taking steps to protect themselves from the risks of conflict between the US and North Korea PMs are portfolio managers, or someone who manages other peopleâ€™s money European stock markets are a sea of red in early trading, with the main indices down around 0.5%. Naeem Aslam of Think Markets explains: The geopolitical tensions have prompted a risk off trade amid investors. President Trumpâ€™s comments about North Korea have created nervousness and the fear is if the president really means what he said â€œfire and furyâ€�. The Japanese yen has hit an eight-week high against the dollar, as geopolitical worries hit the Asian markets. Thatâ€™s significant, as the yen is a classic safe-haven in turbulent times. Todayâ€™s moves drove it up to Â¥109.74, from Â¥110.37 on Tuesday. Mitsuo Imaizumi, chief FX strategist at Daiwa Securities, says (via Reuters) that North Koreaâ€™s threat to attack the island of Guam has spooked traders. â€œThe market had been complacent for a while regarding headlines from North Korea. So it reacted when the North threatened Guam, â€œFew participants, however, think that North Korea would actually strike Guam at this juncture. So the impact is likely to fade eventually.â€� Trumpâ€™s warning to North Korea also sparked a late sell-off on Wall Street last night. That meant the Dow Jones industrial average couldnâ€™t hit its 10th record high in a row. Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and business. Thereâ€™s an old saying in the markets that you should â€œbuy at the sound of cannonsâ€�. Todayâ€™s mantra, though, is that you should sell when the president of the United States and leader of North Korea threaten each other with military conflict. Asian shares have been rattled overnight by the news that Donald Trump had told journalists in New Jersey that: â€œNorth Korea best not make any more threats to the United States. They will be met with fire and the fury like the world has never seen.â€� Trump was responding to reports that North Korea had produced a miniaturised nuclear weapon that can be carried on its intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM). This move raises fears that Pyongyang could launch a pre-emptive attack on the US. As we reported last night: â€œI donâ€™t have the slightest doubt that the RVs on these missiles are working,â€� said Jeffrey Lewis, the director of the East Asia nonproliferation programme at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey. â€œThatâ€™s done. Weâ€™re there. North Korea can put a nuclear weapon on New York City.â€� North Korea swiftly responded to Trumpâ€™s comments, with reports that it was considering attacking the US Pacific territory of Guam, which is a significant US military base. This has a predictably bad effect on the markets, driving money into safe-haven assets such as US government bonds, and out of shares. Japanâ€™s Nikkei index tumbled by 1.5%, while South Koreaâ€™s Kospi 200 index lost 1.25% as traders in Seoul watched events nervously. Itâ€™s not a full-blown crash, of course, but investors do seem to be concerned by the escalating tensions â€œMarkets have a mostly consistent risk-off tone overnight,â€� says Adam Cole of RBC Capital Markets. Weâ€™re also expecting losses in Europe today, with the FTSE 100 being called down 35 points. Jasper Lawler of CMC Markets says: North Korea has been a worry simmering in the background for a long time but with its more advanced weapons and Trump ready to act in the White House, it could bubble over anytime. The threat from North Korea seems to have jolted investors out of their summer slumber. This will also overshadow the 10th anniversary of the financial crisis, which is being marked today. August 9th 2007 was the â€œday the world changedâ€� when central bankers began pumping money into the system, after French bank BNP Paribas barred investors from accessing money in funds exposed to subprime mortgages industry. That was the formal start of the credit crunch, which let to market mayhem, bank collapses, a global recession and the eurozone debt crisis. Weâ€™ll be looking back at what weâ€™ve learned since. The agenda: 10am BST: Bank of England publishes report on how it handles conflicts of interest 10am BST: Greek consumer price inflation figures

fields.body:
Growing tension between the US and North Korea boosted the Swiss franc, the Japanese yen, gold and government bonds as investors sought out traditional safe havens at a time of geopolitical uncertainty.

Nervous trading marked the 10th anniversary of the start of the financial crisis on Wednesday, after Donald Trumpâ€™s warning that North Korea faced â€œfire and fury like the world has never seenâ€� if it continued to make threats against the US.

Gold rose to its highest level in almost two months, while the Swiss franc increased by more than 1% against the US dollar and saw its biggest one-day gain against the euro in more than two and a half years. South Koreaâ€™s won currency dropped 0.9% against the dollar.

Kathleen Brooks, research director at City Index Direct, said: â€œThe Swiss franc is the safe haven of choice today as risk sentiment gets hit from escalating nuclear fears between the US and North Korea. Unsurprisingly, the yen, which is still the second best performer in the G10 foreign exchange space, is playing second fiddle to the Swiss franc due to Japanâ€™s proximity to the epicentre in Pyongyang.â€�

Shares fell in Asian and European trading after Pyongyang responded to the US presidentâ€™s tough language with a threat to launch a nuclear strike on the US Pacific territory of Guam.

Tokyoâ€™s Nikkei index had dropped 1.3% by the time European stock markets opened on Wednesday morning, with similar falls on the German and French bourses. The FTSE 100 ended 44.67 points lower at 7498.06.

But the prospect of hefty losses on Wall Street stocks was averted when US secretary of state Rex Tillerson said there was â€œno imminent threat of warâ€� and that Americans could â€œsleep well at nightâ€�.

US investors saw Tillersonâ€™s comments as evidence that the stand-off between Washington and Pyongyang would be settled by diplomacy rather than by military means. Falls of just 0.3% were recorded by both the Dow Jones industrial average and the more broad-based S&P 500 in early trading.

Mike van Dulken, head of research at Accendo Markets, said: â€œEquities are nursing losses thanks to an unwelcome escalation in geopolitical tensions between the US and North Korea, both trading nuclear threats that have awoken volatility from its slumber and seen risk assets shunned in favour of the traditional safe havens.â€�

In another sign of the risk-averse mood, investors moved money into government bonds. The yield â€“ or interest rate â€“ on a benchmark 10-year US Treasury bill dropped to 2.24%, while a 10-year German bund was yielding 0.43%.

Gold rose 0.6% to $1,268 (Â£976) an ounce and platinum gained 0.6% to reach $972.95 an ounce, having hit its highest since April at $979. Silver rose 1.7% to $16.70 per ounce.

â€œThe market hates uncertainty and thatâ€™s certainly what we have now,â€� said Ole Hansen, head of commodity strategy at Saxo Bank.

fields.body:
The latest housing finance figures reveal that the housing boom might be coming to an end as investors disappear from the market but it appears that the market will need to cool for a while longer before first-home buyers will be able to return in force.

Figures released this week by the Bureau of Statistics reveal that, over the past six months, the growth of housing finance has stalled.

The drop off in the growth of housing finance was rather sudden â€“ after going backwards during 2015, housing finance grew strongly in 2016, reaching a peak monthly growth in October of 1.6%. But, in the first six months of this year, housing finance has never grown by more than 1% in any month:

The main reason for the slowing has been the retreat of investors from the housing market.

In December last year investors accounted for 49.3% of all housing finance â€“ by June this had fallen to just 45.8%:

In the first six months of this year the value of investor housing fell 6%.

But the market hasnâ€™t fallen hard. The signs are there that the hoped for â€œsoft landingâ€� is occurring. While investor finance has fallen, the value of owner-occupier finance has continued to grow â€“ up 7% in the first half of this year:

The slowing of housing finance is a clear sign that the housing market itself should begin to cool. There is a quite solid link between the annual growth of finance and the growth of house prices in six monthsâ€™ time:

These figures suggest the growth of house prices across Australia on average should continue to rise for another three to six months before slowing towards the end of the year.

Thatâ€™s good news for those looking to get into the housing market, especially in Sydney.

While in New South Wales the number of people taking out housing finance continues to grow, the value of that finance is not growing anywhere near the levels it was in 2015:

As a general rule, the growth in the value of housing finance rises in line with the number of people taking out mortgages. In the past six months, however, the growth in value has actually been slightly lower than would be expected given the number of mortgages being entered into:

The hope is that this will see first-home buyers able to return to the market.

Since the end of 2011, when the RBA began cutting rates and set fire to the Sydney housing market, first-home buyers have been shut out.

In January 2012, first-home buyers accounted for 19% of owner-occupiers taking out mortgages; now it is 8%. The drop in first-home buyers occurred across the nation â€“ except for WA â€“ where, due to the end of the mining boom, house prices have fallen by around 8% since the middle of 2014:

The drop in the share of first-home buyers in NSW since 2012, however, is remarkable even compared to the second biggest market of Victoria.

Since 2001 Victoria and NSW had had similar shared of first-home buyers but, in 2012, as the Sydney housing boom took off, the percentage of first-home buyers shrank in a manner not replicated in Victoria:

While the hope for a soft landing, which does not see a collapse in the housing market (and with it a large section of our economy), the concern is that even a slowing of the market will do little to bring back first-home buyers.

Interestingly, since the start of the housing boom, the size of the average mortgage of first-home buyers across all states except Tasmania has increased by less than has the size in the mortgages for non first-home buyers.

A look at the average mortgage sizes in NSW shows that in 2013 the average non first-home buyer mortgage of $335,900 was just 4.5% bigger than the $321,500 average mortgage of a first-home buyer.

Now, however, the average mortgage of a non first-home buyer in NSW is nearly 20% more than for a first-home buyer:

But while the size of mortgages for first-home buyers has stayed steady around $367,000 since the start of 2016, the percentage of first-home buyers in the NSW market has fallen from 9% to 8%.

This suggests that the problem is not so much that the prices of houses bought by first-home buyers has risen but that the number of houses first-home buyers can afford has shrunk. It would suggest that there is a ceiling that many first-home buyers hit of which there is not an equivalent for non-first home buyers.

So while the market might be cooling, it would seem that first-home buyers â€“ especially in Sydney â€“ will be waiting some while before affordability is significantly improved.

The property market has ground to a halt, with activity back to 2011 levels in some parts of the UK, according to the official surveyorsâ€™ body, which blamed â€œpolitical uncertaintyâ€� and forecast flat prices and rents for at least the next year.

A large majority of surveyors in both London and south-east England are reporting falling prices, though the national picture is balanced by price rises in the West Midlands, the south-west and Northern Ireland.

The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors ( Rics) said: â€œRecord low stock numbers, political uncertainty and the aftermath of tax changes are obstacles hindering the UK housing market, with price growth and sales activity subdued during the month of July.â€�

Its poll of valuers around the UK found â€œthe softest reading since early 2013â€�, while south-east England posted â€œthe weakest reading for this part of the country since 2011â€�.

Related: House price slowdown is excellent news â€“Â even if estate agents disagree | Nils Pratley

Homes over Â£1m are having the most difficulty finding buyers, with many sellers having to accept price cuts. â€œAt a national level, 68% of contributors identified homes valued over Â£1m as experiencing the greatest deviation when agreeing final prices.â€�

Mark Everett of the Michael Everett estate agency in Epsom told the survey: â€œThe market is desperately price-sensitive and too much stock is unrealistically overpriced.â€�

In Ipswich, David Knights of David Brown & Co said: â€œThe election result and all the talk of Brexit has had a profound effect on the market, and with high stamp duty charges, sales as well as new instructions are now suffering. Add to this the holiday season and the market is not very clever.â€�

In East Grinsted, Phillip Hiatt of Your Move said: â€œVendors of older stock [are] having to look at price reductions to achieve a sale.â€�

In London, surveyors blame stamp duty, changes in tax on buy-to-let properties and Brexit for a sharp slowdown in the market. Stamp duty on a Â£1m home in London â€“ not uncommon in many parts of the capital â€“ now costs a buyer Â£43,750, prompting campaigners to call for cuts to the tax.

â€œ[George] Osborneâ€™s hike in stamp duty has had a negative effect. Removing interest relief for landlords is causing some to sell, [with] few sales now to investors,â€� said Allen Fuller estate agents in Putney.

Rents are also falling in the capital. Simon Aldous of Savills said: â€œRents continue to fall slowly. We have seen seven consecutive quarters of marginal falls in rents.â€�

But in other parts of the UK, valuers are reporting buoyant activity. In Liverpool, Derek Coates of Venmore described July as â€œa strangely busy month considering external factors and the time of year. The investor market has been extremely busy, particularly from out-of-town investors.â€�

The net balance of surveyors reporting price rises fell from +7% to +1% in July, signalling that prices were broadly flat across the country. In London, the net balance reporting price rises was strongly negative, at -48%.

Surveyors were also asked by Rics to give their forecast on house prices. â€œNear-term price expectations continue to signal a flat trend over the coming three months at the headline level. Over the next 12 months, respondents remain more optimistic, with a net balance of +28% anticipating an increase in prices, albeit this was the least positive reading since last July, at the time of the EU referendum results. Again, central London continues to exhibit the most cautious 12-month projections relative to all other parts of the UK.â€�

Rics said it expected rents to rise no more than 2% nationally over the next year. â€œAlthough tenant demand continued to edge higher, it did so at the slowest quarterly pace going back nearly 20 years. Meanwhile, landlord instructions continued to fall, with 8% of respondents reporting a decline instead of an increase in listings.

â€œThe sustained lack of supply means rents are expected to grow, albeit only modestly in the coming three months.â€�

webTitle: 'Political uncertainty' blamed for slowdown in UK property market

fields.body:
5.54pm BST

European markets slump on North Korea tensions

The increasingly tense confrontation between the US and North Korea has again sent investors fleeing from equities and into safer areas such as gold and government bonds. It was a down day across Europe, while Wall Street was also suffering from the growing uncertainty. David Madden, market analyst at CMC Markets UK, said:

The showdown between the two nations has scared off many investors. Whenever dealers hear the word â€˜warâ€™ they usually run for the hills, and that is exactly what we have seen today. While tensions are running high, traders will be reluctant to be long...

US equity markets are holding up better than their European equivalents, but a global story like this will shake investors out of the stock markets. US equities, and in particular, the Dow Jones had a great run recently and the political uncertainly between the two countries has encouraged profit taking.

The final scores in Europe showed:

  • The FTSE 100 fell 108.12 points or 1.44% to 7389.94, wiping around Â£27bn off the value of the UKâ€™s top companies and marking its worst one day performance since 18 April this year
  • Germanyâ€™s Dax is down 1.15% to 12,014.30
  • Franceâ€™s Cac closed 0.59% lower at 5115.23
  • Italyâ€™s FTSE MIB fell 0.76% to 21,681.61
  • Spainâ€™s Ibex ended down 1.38% at 10,450.0
  • But in Greece, the Athens market added 0.02% to 833.78

On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently down 165 points or 0.74%, on track for its worst day since the end of June.

On that note, itâ€™s time to close for the evening. Thanks for all your comments, and weâ€™ll be back tomorrow.

4.34pm BST

Meanwhile the Vix volatility index has jumped 27% on the North Korea situation, hitting a three month high of 14.2.

4.26pm BST

The fall in the FTSE 100 is due in the most part to the global concerns following the growing tensions between the US and North Korea, but there are other factors.

For a start, some 40 points of the current 114 point or 1.52% decline is due to companies being quoted ex-dividend. Then there is the widening UK trade deficit, as well as news that the NIESR think tank had edged its growth forecast lower.

And housebuilders have been hit by signs of the weakening housing market. Joshua Mahony, market analyst at IG, said:

The housing market decline evident within London over recent months appears to be spreading across the country, with the latest report from RICS highlighting a slowdown in sales. Yesterdayâ€™s report from the London School of Economics and VATT suggested the recent stamp duty changes are having a significant negative effect on housing transactions, and today we are seeing that borne out in the RICS data. The continued slowdown we are seeing in house price growth and housing sales is proving a drag on the housebuilder sector, with Barratt Developments and Taylor Wimpey suffering heavily today.

3.30pm BST

The market slide is continuing, as investors flee to safer areas given the tensions between the US and North Korea. Connor Campbell, financial analyst at Spreadex, said:

The US open did nothing to dispel the dayâ€™s tremulous trading, instead causing the European indices to intensify their own losses.

The Dow Jones plunged more than half a percent after the bell, wiping off 130 points to leave the index teetering just above 21900. Thatâ€™s its worst price since the end of July, raising questions of whether this is the end of the Dowâ€™s recent record run, or just a brief diversion until the US/North Korea situation cools and a parade of proper, Grade A data arrives (for example, next week is looking pretty jam-packed).

The Dowâ€™s drop had serious implications for the rest of the global markets, as investors voiced their concerns about the nuclear threat posed by two very spoilt children. The FTSE is now down a whopping 1.6% â€“ and while roughly third of that decline stems from a chunk of the index going ex-dividend, the rest certainly doesnâ€™t. Not only is the war of words (letâ€™s hope their spat remains verbal) between Trump and Kim Jong Un weighing on the FTSE, but also the disappointment of Juneâ€™s 9 month high UK trade deficit.

There were similarly alarming slides in the Eurozone. The DAX gradually saw its losses widen to 130 points, sending the German index to a fresh 12 week nadir, while the CAC dropped 0.7% to lurk just above 5100.

2.59pm BST

Opec raises forecast for oil demand

Opec has forecast higher demand for crude in 2018, and said a rise in the oil price suggested its moves to curb the glut of supply could be having an effect.

In its monthly report, the oil producers organisation said demand next year would reach 32.42m barrels a day, up 220,000 from its previous prediction.

The news has helped push Brent crude 0.9% higher to $53.19 a barrel.

2.38pm BST

Wall Street follows other global markets lower

US markets have opened lower, with investors nervy amid the rhetoric from the US and North Korea.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 79 points or 0.36% in early trading, pushing it back below the 22,000 level, while the S&P 500 opened down 0.43% and the Nasdaq Composite 0.65% lower.

Meanwhile the FTSE 100 is 1.26% lower and set for its worst day since mid-April. But around 40 points of the near 100 point decline is due to a number of major companies being quoted ex-dividend, when shareholders no longer have the right to the payout.

Updated at 2.52pm BST

2.29pm BST

Also from the US, producer price inflation came in weaker than expected, another suggestion that any imminent rate rise from the Federal Reserve is unlikely. James Knightley, chief international economist at ING Bank, said:

US PPI comes in well below expectations, suggesting that there is little need for imminent additional policy tightening. Nonetheless, we still see some potential for higher inflation to year end.

The US PPI report for July is surprisingly low, falling 0.1% month on month (consensus was looking for a 0.1% rise), which brings the year on year rate down to 1.9% from 2%. The market and ourselves had been looking for 2.2% or 2.3% year on year reading. Core (excluding food and energy) similarly fell one tenth of a point.

This is the first month on month drop in the headline rate since August 2016 and on the face of it a suggests pretty benign inflation backdrop right now...

It is a surprise because the building blocks pointed to a much strong reading. The combination of the 10% fall in the US dollar helping to nudge up import prices, rising commodity prices (such as oil, which rose 18% trough to peak between June and July) and the underlying strength in the manufacturing sector helping to give a bit more pricing power to producers.

Todayâ€™s softer outcome suggests some downside risk for tomorrowâ€™s CPI report, but with the economy growing reasonably and creating jobs in significant numbers, coupled with the factors we cited regarding PPI mean we still think inflation pressures will pick-up over coming months.

Updated at 2.30pm BST

1.43pm BST

Newsflash from America: The number of US citizens filing new claims for unemployment benefit has risen slightly.

Around 244,000 new â€˜initial joblessâ€™ claims were filed last week, up from 241,000 in the previous seven days.

Thatâ€™s still a low figure, by historical standards, showing how the US labor market remains pretty solid.

1.14pm BST

NIESR: UK growth rate has slowed

Newsflash: Britainâ€™s economy only grew by 0.2% in the last three months, according to the latest estimate from The National Institute Of Economic and Social Research Research.

If NIESR are right, that means that growth slowed in July, following 0.3% growth in April-June.

Itâ€™s much slower than the UKâ€™s trend growth rate, of around 0.5-0.6%, and dangerously close to stagnation.

Amit Kara, head of UK macroeconomic Forecasting at NIESR, said:

â€œWe estimate that economic growth decelerated to 0.2 per cent in the three months to July, compared with 0.3 per cent in the second quarter of 2017. The service sector, which was the main driver for economic growth in the second quarter, appears to have slowed. We see a modest recovery in the second half of this year in response to strengthening global growth and a weaker currency, but on the flip side, consumer spending is likely to be weighed down by weak wage growth and investment spending held back by Brexit-related uncertainty.

Further out, we see quarterly economic growth strengthen somewhat to 0.4-0.5 per cent as the economy rebalances away from domestic demand and towards net trade. Economic growth however, remains below its long-run average growth rate of 0.6 per cent because of subdued productivity growthâ€�.

1.05pm BST

EIU: Korean conflict is unlikely, but.....

Mike Jakeman, global analyst at the Economist Intelligence Unit. argues that there is only a small chance that the United States and North Korea end up going to war.

But while thatâ€™s a relief, Jakeman also fears that Trumpâ€™s â€œbellicose rhetoricâ€� is dangerous, and could drive the two sides into conflict.

He says:

â€œRhetoric between the US and the North has intensified over the past year, as evidence has mounted that North Korea is capable of attaching a miniaturised warhead to the top of an intercontinental missile. US intelligence agencies now believe North Korea can do this. The remaining challenge for the North is manufacturing a warhead that can survive the heat of re-entering the earthâ€™s atmosphere from space. However, North Koreaâ€™s complete dedication to its nuclear programme, combined with the accelerating progress of recent months, means that this final hurdle is likely to be cleared shortly.

Mr Trump believes that the previous US policy of â€œstrategic patienceâ€� failed because it permitted the development of the Northâ€™s missiles and warheads. But there is little indication that his bellicose rhetoric is intimidating North Koreaâ€™s supreme leader, Kim Jong-un. Indeed, so far as Kim Jong-un is strengthened by evidence of the USâ€™s threat to the North, it cements him in his position and justifies his own aggression.

The danger in the USâ€™s strategy of matching the Northâ€™s shrill rhetoric is that the escalating threats lead each to assume the other is moving closer to an attack, until such a confrontation becomes inevitable. The Economist Intelligence Unit believes this risk remains lowâ€”a nuclear war would have catastrophic consequencesâ€”but that it is rising in proportion to the strengthening of the rhetoric. The positions of two of the three of the main actors are clear. The North will continue to develop its nuclear weapons programme regardless of the USâ€™s threats or any economic pressure generated by tighter international sanctions. China will recalibrate its trade and diplomacy with North Korea in line with UN sanctions, but will avoid instability. The USâ€™s position is the most fluid. A pivot from aggression to containment is likely in the medium term, but the risk of an attack to attempt to damage North Koreaâ€™s military capabilities in the short term has risen again.â€�

12.44pm BST

The 2% jump in British exports to Europe in April-June shows why we need a full trade deal with the EU after Brexit, says the Institute of Directors.

Updated at 1.18pm BST

11.50am BST

The US stock market is expected to fall when it opens in three hours time.

New York traders will probably be cautious, following North Koreaâ€™s dismissal of Donald Trumpâ€™s â€˜fire and furyâ€™ threat, as a â€˜load of nonsenseâ€™.

The Dow Jones industrial average is being called down nearly 50 points,. That would drag it below the 22,000 mark, hit for the first time this month.

Heightened geopolitical tensions will weigh on shares today, predicts Marketwatch:

David Madden of CMC Markets reckons traders are on â€˜red alertâ€™, in case the situation deteriorates further.

Madden adds:

In tense situation like this, equity markets are move lower exceptionally fast, and investors donâ€™t want to be caught on the wrong side of the markets, so they are getting out now.

Traders would require nerves of steel to starting buying into the stock market now, given standoff between the US and North Korea.

11.26am BST

Damian Green, the UKâ€™s first secretary of state and effectively deputy prime minister, has urged the US government to use United Nationâ€™s processes to resolve the North Korea crisis after President Donald Trump threatened â€œfire and furyâ€� against the Pyongyang regime.

Green was asked by reporters on a visit to Edinburgh whether he thought Trumpâ€™s rhetoric was unhelpful or wise given the escalating tensions.

He replied:

â€œI think the sensible way for people to proceed now is to work through the UN process: thatâ€™s what the British government has been supporting and will continue to support.

â€œWe think that over the past months the North Korean government has not been behaving properly and I hope they respond to pressure from the UN.â€�

Asked what the UK governmentâ€™s position was on the crisis, he underlined the UKâ€™s preference for a UN-brokered resolution.

â€œItâ€™s obviously in all our interests to make sure that nothing escalates. We are very strongly in support of the UN process, which has and continues to put pressure on North Korea to stop acting in an irresponsible way and we will continue strongly to support the UN process which will I hope help to deescalate tensions.â€�

Updated at 12.42pm BST

11.20am BST

UK exports to Europe jumped in last quarter

Britainâ€™s exports to the EU jumped by 2% in the last three months, but exports to non-EU countries actually fell by 1.4%, according to todayâ€™s trade data.

Liberal Democrat leader Sir Vince Cable says it shows that certain promises made during the EU referendum are unfulfilled.

Cable explains:

â€œAs with the extra Â£350m a week for the NHS, the export boom dreamed up by the Brexiteers is nowhere to be seen.

â€œThe fall in the pound since the referendum has not given a significant boost to UK exporters, but has instead driven up the cost of imports for both businesses and consumers.

â€œAs any half-decent economist will tell you, countries trade most with their closest neighbours. That is why Europe remains by far the UKâ€™s most important export market.

â€œThis underlines the need to protect UK exporters and control our trade deficit by remaining in the single market and customs union.â€�

Updated at 12.43pm BST

11.07am BST

European selloff picks up pace

The selloff in the financial markets is accelerating, as nervousness over the North Korean situation continues to grip trading floors.

Britainâ€™s FTSE 100 has now slid by 80 points, or 1%, and other indices are all in the red too.

European investors are following the lead from Asia overnight, where most markets fell and the South Korean won hit a one-month low.

The potential of armed conflict between North Korea and the US is a serious concern for investors.

The news that Pyongyang is officially working on a plan to attack Guam has added to concerns, deterring them from holding riskier assets. Instead, theyâ€™re looking to hold gold (at a two-month high today), the Japanese yen, and US government bonds.

Joshua Mahony of IG says

For now, tensions are high, yet in all likeliness we will see this intensity simmer down somewhat, with both sides standing to lose more than they would gain from military action.

10.51am BST

Howard Archer, Chief Economic Advisor to the EY ITEM Club, is also disappointed by Britainâ€™s trade data:

A fall in exports and rise in imports caused the monthly trade deficit to nearly double. And, a deficit of Â£8.9bn in the second quarter of 2017 suggests that net trade made no contribution to growth in the quarter.

Evidence of rebalancing, at least in the â€˜hardâ€™ data, remains absent.â€�

10.27am BST

No sign of Britainâ€™s economy rebalancing here....

10.25am BST

Ranko Berich, Head of Market Analysis at Monex Europe, fears that Britainâ€™s trade gap will get worse before it gets better.

He says:

â€œThe export-driven pickup in manufacturing, hoped for by some, has yet to materialise in the UK, despite survey data from the sector remaining reasonably optimistic. Instead, Manufacturing Production remained flat on the month while the goods trade balance fell further into negatives.

â€œFollowing a large currency shock, the sort we saw in the aftermath of the referendum, adjustments in trade balance typically follow a â€œJ-Curveâ€�, at first getting worse before they improve. Of course, itâ€™s a long way from economic theory to reality and the length of this adjustment process is highly variable and difficult to predict, but Juneâ€™s data suggest weâ€™re not quite at the bottom yet, to say the least.â€�

Hereâ€™s what a J-Curve looks like, via the National Graduate Institute for Policy Studies:

More details here, for readers who enjoy an economics lecture.

10.17am BST

BCC: Britain's trade figures are disappointing

In theory, a weak currency ought to help a countryâ€™s exporters and improve its trade figures.

But todayâ€™s data show that this isnâ€™t really happening in Britain, as it continues to consume more goods and services than it sells to the rest of the world.

Thatâ€™s because modern trade is complex, with many companies buying raw materials or parts from abroad before selling their finished goods overseas.

Suren Thiru, Head of Economics at the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC) explains:

â€œThe sharp deterioration in the UKâ€™s net trade position in June was disappointing, and means the trade deficit in the second quarter of this year came in slightly higher than in the previous quarter. Taken together with the recent jump in the current account deficit, signals the continued weakness of the UKâ€™s external position. The widening in the UK trade deficit in June was largely driven by a sharp rise in imports.

â€œBusinesses continue to report that the slump in the value of sterling since the EU referendum remains something of a double-edged sword, as many exporters are also importers, and so face higher input costs due to the weakening currency. While stronger global economic growth may help to boost the UKâ€™s export performance over the second half of the year, it is unlikely to be sufficient to prevent an overall weakening in growth.

This chart, from todayâ€™s trade reports, underlines how thereâ€™s been no real improvement in Britainâ€™s trade gap since the Brexit vote:

10.07am BST

Ms Lee Hopley, chief economist at EEF, the manufacturersâ€™ organisation, warns there are â€œscant signsâ€� in todayâ€™s data that net trade could give Britainâ€™s economy a growth burst.

Ben Wright of the Daily Telegraph agrees that the goods trade figures are bad:

10.02am BST

The ONS has also reported that UK manufacturing output was flat in June, meeting City forecasts.

However, the wider measure of industrial production jumped by 0.5% in the month - beating expectations.

9.59am BST

Economist Rupert Seggins reminds us that Britain hasnâ€™t achieved a trade surplus in almost 20 years.....

9.49am BST

Britainâ€™s worsening trade gap was driven a 4.9% slump in the volume of goods exported in June.

Thatâ€™s the worst performance since June 2016, the month of the Brexit referendum.

Updated at 10.11am BST

9.43am BST

UK trade gap widens to nine-month high

Newsflash! Britainâ€™s trade deficit WIDENED by Â£2bn in June, dashing hopes that the gap between imports and exports might have narrowed.

The UKâ€™s total trade deficit in goods and services hit Â£4.6bn in June, up from a (downwardly revised) Â£2.5bn in May. Thatâ€™s the widest deficit in nine months.

The Office for National Statistics blames a surge of imports during June.

It says:

This was mainly due to an increase in imports of both goods and services of Â£1.7 billion.

Of this, imports of goods contributed Â£0.6 billion, with imports in machinery and transport equipment (specifically mechanical machinery, aircraft and road vehicles) from EU countries up by Â£0.5 billion.

The goods deficit swelled to Â£12.7bn, the ONS adds, a worse reading than expected.

More to follow

9.30am BST

Pound hits three-week low

The pound has fallen back through the $1.30 mark this morning, to a three-week low of $1.2952.

Thatâ€™s partly because the dollar is strengthening, as investors look for safe havens.

9.16am BST

The news that North Korea was formulating an attack on Guam sent shares down across Asia.

Sam Chi Yung of South China Financial Holdings said:

â€œThe North Korea situation is still unstable and investors are controlling risk and taking profit after recent gains.â€�

9.08am BST

One of Donald Trumpâ€™s assistants, Sebastian Gorka, spoke about the situation on Radio 4 today:

â€œDonald Trump has been unequivocal: he will use any appropriate measures to protect the United States and her citizens.

We do not telegraph our future scenarios and how we are going to react,â€� he said. â€œIf you show players around a table your poker hand, you will lose that game. It is not a good idea in cards, it is a very bad idea in geopolitics.â€�

8.58am BST

European stock markets have also added to yesterdayâ€™s losses in early trading.

The French, German and UK markets are all in the red in early trading.

In London, the FTSE 100 tumbled by 40 points to a one-week low.

Mining shares are leading the fallers, reflecting concerns that the North Korea crisis could hurt the economy and dent demand for commodities.

Connor Campbell of SpreadEx says:

The FTSE suffered another sharp fall at the open, as the latest developments in the US/North Korea situation weighed on its commodity stocks.....

It appears that Pyongyangâ€™s detailed strike plan against Guam has created a sour backdrop to trading.

(The FTSE 100â€™s decline is also partly because some major companies have gone â€˜ex-dividendâ€™, meaning new shareholders wonâ€™t get the next divi payment).

8.39am BST

Gold rises and Korean won falls

The growing tensions between North Korea and the United States are continuing to weigh on the financial markets today.

The gold price has hit a two-month high this morning, at $1,280.5 per ounce, as investors remain jittery following Donald Trumpâ€™s â€˜fire and furyâ€™ threat earlier this week.

Overnight, North Korea raised the stakes further by outlining a plan to fire a missile into the water near Guam, the US territory in the Pacific.

General Kim Rak Gyom, the head of the countryâ€™s strategic forces, declared that Trump was â€œbereft of reasonâ€�, in a statement that could rile the US president.

My colleague Julian Borger reports:

The response from Pyongyang was its most public and detailed threat to date, and evidently meant to goad the US president.

Trump had â€œlet out a load of nonsense about â€˜fire and furyâ€™ failing to grasp the ongoing grave situation. This is extremely getting on the nerves of the infuriated Hwasong artillerymen of the KPA.â€�

Related: North Korea details Guam strike plan and calls Trump 'bereft of reason'

This is causing understandable concern over the border in South Korea.

South Koreaâ€™s Kospi stock market index has fallen by 0.4% today, adding to the 1% wiped off shares on Wednesday.

The South Korean Won is also suffering, falling by 0.8% to a four-week low against the US dollar.

Although the City isnâ€™t panicking, it is certainly watching the situation closely.

Konstantinos Anthis of ADS Securities says investors are either sitting on the side-lines or looking to sell risky assets and buy safer ones.

The escalation of the rhetoric between the US and North Korea is keeping market participants on their toes and with no fresh economic reports the price action is dictated by the headlines.

Updated at 9.20am BST

8.13am BST

The agenda: UK trade figures

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and business.

Today we discover whether the weak pound is helping Britainâ€™s factories, and making a dent in her trade deficit.

The City is bracing for new UK trade figures at 9.30am; economists predict that the total gap between everything the UK imports and exports narrowed slightly in June, after jumping to Â£3.1bn in May.

HSBC say:

Trade volume growth appears to be moving in the right direction, with exports up 3.8% 3m/3m in May 2017, and imports growing more slowly at 2.8%. And the surveys back up anecdotal evidence that UK exports are responding to sterling weakness.

However, so far, this has done little to reduce the trade deficit in absolute terms. We expect another relatively hefty deficit in June.

New industrial production figures are also being released, and may show that manufacturing output was flat in June, month-on-month. A strong reading might raise hopes that Britainâ€™s growth rate in the second quarter of 2017 could be revised up, from the first estimate of 0.3%.
